Thursday P.M. Dec. 22nd. Washington.
Congress has adjourned without doing anything - and the Secy. of War is 
busy making transfers to the Supernumerary list - they to be discharged January 1st 
in filling up the retired list - and assigning officer to the numerous vacancies. 
A good many resignations are coming in. Gray's has been accepted.
I enclose clips from this mornings Chronicle - which may be of interest to you -
It is that that the Senate has confirmed Ames this P.M. but no one know. His
object is understood to be to get his year pay by going out as a supernumerary -
I dont think that there is any danger of his being sent to a regiment. But if the
Senate has adjourned without confirming him, his case will come up in Jan'y and then
if confirmed he will go to his regt - and for fear of this I hope you will at once write
a letter direct to the Military Com. of the Senate protesting against his confirmation and
giving a brief statement of his troubles and service (!) in the 10th. I will see Senator Wilson also.
I have now for you a bit of news which I got at the War Dept. this morning.
I was told that I must not repeat it - but it won't be secret when you get this -
Carpenter has, on his own request - and by Custer's held, been transferred to the 7th Cav.
The order was issued yesterday - but not published. I am still unassigned and 
the vacancies of Carpenter & Gray in the 10th - to be filled -
I hope you may get several bits of news by this. Please write to me
HEA

In Virginia.
Wednesday, January 11. 1871.
Dear General
Although I had about made up my mind
that I would go out of the service as unassigned on the 31st
ultimo, there was doubt enough about it to make me
feel right uneasy until the orders were published. The 
order, dated 2nd Jan'y. was not published until the 6th and 
I got it on the 9th. By it I am surprised to find myself
assigned to the 9th Cavalry. Notwithstanding your 
letter I felt a good deal of doubt about my being reassigned to
the Cavalry even if I was retained, and I took it for granted
that if put in the Cavalry it would be the Tenth, upon your 
request should a vacancy exist there. After the first
order filling the places of Cox and Graham I knew of no
vacancy to be except Gray's, of that I spoke to the Adjt Gnl.
and the only other regiments named, in case I could not go to
the Tenth were the First and Fifth, in both of which I have
many friends. You may judge therefore of my surprise
at finding myself put in the Ninth especially when I see 
that there was plenty of room in the Tenth, - more particularly
as my old company was left open by Capt. Burke's transfer to
the supe's and I might just as well have been sent to that 
as Capt. Norvell, an infantry officer who goes there.
I am assigned to "M." Co. of the 9th. Is it possible that 
it was intended to send me to "M." of the 10th and that a mistake occurred?

By the terms of the order. I being on duty under a "special assignment", I do not join my regiment at once 
remain for the present at Amherst.
Co. "M" of the Ninth is now at Fort McKavett, Texas.
When I shall go there of course I cannot tell. I am very contented at Amherst, and while I shall, of course, 
stand ready to obey orders at any time. I don't propose to take any action to hasten my being relieved from duty
at the College.
I have thought of going to the Dept. to my to get my order
changed, before the officers generally join their regiments,
but I have been told that Gen. Sherman has little influence
with the Secretary, that the latter is very irritable, and that 
officers better not show their heads there.
The changes in the Tenth won't quite suit you, I
imagine. I judge you will be glad to have Armes,
Cox, Graham, Gray and Burke out of the way, but a good deal
will depend upon how their successors turn out. I Know only 
two of the new Col assigned, of those I  wrote you recently.
Of Byrne's case I do not know enough to make comments.
I think, on the whole, you will be glad to retain Nolan.
I am sorry I wrote what I did about Carpenter, - and hope 
you said nothing to him about it. I was told positively 
that the order had been made out my authority being an A.D.C.
at Army Hd, Qrs. an A.A.G. on duty at the War Dept. and a field 
officer of the Seventh Cavalry.

In replacing Yard by Schofield, provided the latter even 
joins for duty, you have undoubtedly gained. I see he is in your 
Dept. and not with his brother, as I had supposed.
The change from Kidd to McKibben I have more doubt about.
He may prove O.K. but I think he has seen no mounted service and 
had there been one more Major dropped out, he would have been the man.
I presume you will be disgusted, as I am, at the return to duty
of Spencer and Doyle. I really don't see how the Board could 
pass over the evidence against them. As I wrote you, Lt.
Spencer used language no reference to you, while in Washington, in the
presence of Kidd, Nolan, Harmon and myself, which would cashier 
him before any honest Court. But the latter is rarely found!
I hear that Spencer, who was or rather tried to be very loving towards
me at the Ebbitt House, has, since he heard my evidence in his case 
amused himself by filing a set of changes against me. Of what they 
consist I do not Know. but as I have not served with the regt. when he
was with it, for over two years, I don't feel particularly alarmed!
You have a good many new officers in the South and I hope 
they will turn out well for you and the regiment. Especially
I hope my old Co. will get a good Captain.
Altogether there have been thirty-three (33) new Captains put
into the Cavalry, and of these full 25 never served mounted.
The result leaves me two or three files lower in the lineal list than 
I was a year ago. I am 8th Captain in my new regiment.
I should be the 8th were I in the 10th. Among the Captains
assigned to the Cavalry are six who never served mounted, who outrank

all the old Cavy. Captains - i.e. Capt. Huntt and McLaughlin 
who have stood at the head of the Cavalry Linear List for a
year - will now have six or seven standing above them, to be 
made Majors of Cav. first, - altho' they are all "do' boys."
This is pretty rough, I think, and Cav. Capts. of good standing
will have reason to complain.
Mrs. Alvord has been with me spending the Holiday 
vacation with our Virginia relatives, and after a very nice
visit we now propose to start Friday on our return to 
Amherst. That will be my P.O. address.
Present our regards to Mrs. Grierson and all friends.
Ever truly - your friend.
and obedient servant
Henry E. Alvord
Genl. Grierson
Col. 10th Cav.
U.S.A.

Military Department.
Massachusetts Agricultural College,
AMHERST, March 12th, 1871
Dear General.
I am indebted to you for two letters dated respctively 
the 26th of Jan'y and the 2nd of Feb'y. which I received within a few
days of one another, during the last half of February. From the
length of time that they were on the road, and their appearance on 
arrival I judge that you are still trouble in the Territory with high
water at times, causing stoppages, delays and damage to the mails.
I am sure I have written to you since the reorganization, but 
cannot give the exact date. It must have been about Jan'y 10th.
I fell quite sure that the intention had been to send me to my 
old company, but that thro' some error, very likely by a clerk, I was 
assigned to 'M.' Troop of the Ninth instead of the Tenth. As I had
used no pressure to accomplish my retention, I was naturally quite
pleased at the recognition of my services by my reassignment to the 
Cavalry, but I was by no means satisfied with the regiment, and I at
once prepared to secure a change. I now remember that I wrote 
to you between the time I first saw G.O. No. 1. '71 and my first visit there, 
after to Washington. I went to the War Dept. as soon as I could,
got Capt. Norvell's address (he was then at St. Paul) ascertained by enquiry
that there was no reason to suppose that he would not as soon join the
Ninth as the Tenth, and I then proceeded to propose the change to him.

For that purpose I went to the room of Gen. Sherman's A.D.C's
were I have before been favored with writing facilities, and there in a
chance conversation with Col. Audenreid and others I was told
that I had better not attempt any change, at present, at any rate.
The Secretary had lost his wife in the midst of his busiest time, and
by the very M.C's who had voted the reduction he had been bothered to
death to give places to their proteges, also by officers pleading their own 
causes. As a result the Honorable gentleman had become unbearably
cross, and it was said to be all an officer's commission was worth
to show himself at the Secretary's office. They told me that
one officer who had been assigned by the first order, and dissatisfied
with the regiment had sought a change, was, by the last order put back
among the unassigned, and mustered out; - that a Lieutenant who had
used great influence to get assigned to the 5th Art. and had been put in the 3rd
by G.O. No.1, immediately, on the strength of his previous introduction, applied
at once for a transfer from 3d to 5th, was edified by an order revoking
his assignment to the Art'y, and sending him to Infty. in the North West.
So; after deliberation, I regretfully desisted from my purpose.
I suppose that, by this time, Capt. Norvell has joined you. I hope
he will prove more satisfactory than Capt. Burke, and make a good
commander to'M' Troop. Have you heard anything from 
Capt. Carleton? I suppose he is still at Miami Univ. Oxford Ohio.
I have no intimation yet of orders to join my regiment, and it 
has been promised to friends of the College that I shall remain this year.

While I do not propose to meddle with the matter, I shall be 
glad to stay, and am pleased consequently to know that the Mass'tts. State 
authorities will do what they can to have me retained.
Co."M." of the Ninth is at Fort McKavett, Texas. - I have made
my personal monthly reports but heard nothing in return.
I do not fancy, at present, the idea of service in Texas, and I can 
not now tell what action I should take upon an order to join my regt.
Should I go to the regt. I should probably ask you to send a note to Col.
Hatch. to let him know something of my service with you, as I should
be an entire stranger in the regiment, Lt. Col. Merritt excepted, and the 
latters position, I imagine, has been similar to that of J.W.D. in the Tenth.
What do you think of the changes of Station of the Cavalry Regt's.
I reason thus:- The 3rd & 8th have recently changed places so that they will
not be likely to change again soon. The Pacific claims the 1st. as its reg't.
The 7th is about coming East, and South, the 6th moves to the place of the 7th.
This leaves the 2nd & 4th to consider. I should not be surprised if they
were some day ordered to change places. The 7th will not be likely
to remain long in the South, it must go West again at the next Presidential 
campaign, if not before. Where will it go? Texas is the spot
weakened by the 7th being in the South. There will soon be a Pacific R.R.
building in that State, calling for troops. The Seventh will most 
likely be sent to Texas when they go West, but they have seen your country
and they will make a desperate fight for that. It will be, in fact it is

already, argued that Texas is the place for the colored troops.
So, altho' I apprehend no such move at present. I advise you
to watch the board, and be prepared to check any such attempt.
I trust that when you get all your new men in sight, you
will be able to draw up the new reorganized regimental slate
satisfactorily. You know very well that I would gladly talk
over the matters with you, as you say, - for I think we agree very 
well in our estimate of the subaltern officers of the Tenth.
I have been wondering what officer you would send on
Recruiting service for the regt. under General Orders. You will
not be inclined to send any at present. I think,- but you must
do it sooner or later. Looking the list over it seems to me 
that when Robinson returns. Morrison will be the best man
to send recruiting. I really think he would work well, and 
that, all considered, it would be about the best thing to be done.
Pratt would do well, no doubt, and be glad of the work, but
he has been East on a good long visit once, and you can
hardly spare him, at any rate.
Carpenter certainly had excellent reasons for staying at Sill.
As to Spencer, I have heard nothing of any little attention
paid to me by him, in the way of charges, and don't expect to.
I have not yet drafted charges and specifications against
him as you requested, but I will do so soon, and send them.
Specifications of that nature must be very carefully worded

2.
and I want the time to look up the authorities before I write
them out. I have not had that time lately as I have been 
engaged every moment of my time, Sundays excepted, since my 
return to the Term duties. My heaviest work this session
is the preparation of a series of lectures on Military Art & History
which I am delivering to the Senior Class. It is new work for 
me and comes rather hard. I spent all the time I could 
spare while in Washington, in the Library of Congress and the
War Dept. Library, but that was insufficient and I have much 
studying and writing to do now. I estimate that every 
hour I spend with the class requires at least twenty five hours 
of hard work in preparation. At present I am upon the
History of Cavalry and I find the subject of much interest.
I am trying to get at what you requested, but am afraid I
shall not succeed. Congress has not yet authorized the new
regulations and they have not been printed. Even Senator Wilson
who is pressing the bill to authorize them seems to know very little about'em.
I got a glimpse at the Cavalry Tactics in manuscript, in General
Sherman's office in Dec'r. I think Col. Dayton was looking the
work over with the General until he left, and that one of the new Cav'y
Aids (there are 3 Cav. Capts. there now), has the job at present. They
seem to be in no hurry about it. Capt. Bates the Cav'y. Instructor
at West Point writes me that he has no idea what changes have been
made but that he is authorize to use "old 1841" during this year.
I understand that the new Register is in press, and I will get
an advanced copy if I can. Should think that the G.O.No.
would answer your purpose for the present, tho it gives no lineal
lists.

I trust that before long you will find time to write
the long letter you promise in these before me. I know
you are good for it when you get started, and how interesting 
it will be. Surrounded by persons and objects familiar to me
events daily occurring in which I am much interested, you have 
every advantage of me in the way of material for letters.
Have you sen what a pretty mess General Eli Parker got 
into. Altho' fairly white-washed by the investigating committee
he was thoroughly cornered by Mr. Welsh of the Commission, and
the pamphlet which Mr. Welch has published is a most convincing
thing. The Commission has a new lease of life & usefulness
with largely increased powers.
I had a letter from Edward Lewis yesterday. He is at
work for Dr. G. H. Perry at Manhattan, Kas. and wants me to
pay his fare to Mass'tts. and take it out in work, but I fear
I shall not be convinced.
With kind regards from both of us, to you and yours,
always ready and eager to read all you will write, and glad 
to send all I have of interest.
I remain ever,
respectfully and very truly yours,
Henry E Alvord
Gen'l Grierson.
Col. 10th Cav'y
U.S.A.

Spring Hill Farm, Virginia.
June 9. 1872.
Dear General,
It seems hardly possible that, as good friends as we
have been, we should have allowed more than a year to pass without any
direct communication, and no matter how busy we may have been. I think
we ought to be ashamed of ourselves and mend our ways, in this respect.
For months I have been saying to myself and to Martha, 'I must write 
to General Grierson next Sunday', but have not done it, till now.
I am brought to the "sticking point" today by two things, mainly:-
1st. The heat of a June day keeping me under cover, and 2nd, the feeling
that I must ask you to take some proper and prompt notice of Gen'l. Hazen's
letter to the N.Y. Tribune and republished in The Army and Navy Journal, and
other papers. The great Indian manager (!) goes a long way out of 
his proper course on his way to his new post, to make a direct and what
seems to me a most malicious attack upon the general management of
the Fort Sill. Reservation if not upon its commandant personally.
He writes similar letters so often that in the East and outside of
Army circles, his statements go a good way. Once before I had to correct 
some of them by a letter to The Times, but those were not over his name. These
bring backed by his signature ought to receive attention at the hands of his
equal in rank, U.S.V. or U.S.A. as well as in Indian management, and by
name still more widely and favorably known. Although he represents
himself as very desirous of disciplining the unruly Comanches and Kiowas, and
says plainly he believes you would have rewarded Satanta & Co. for their boasting
and let them go, had not Gen'l. Sherman have been there, we can well

remember his frequent presents to the worst of the Reservation leaders,
and his refusal to sanction the arrest by you of Indian known to have
committed murders on the Reserve, when his consent was necessary to 
such action, you wanting nothing else.
As to his sweeping assertions as to the connection between the 
Indians in your charge and the Howard's Wells and other tragedys,
since both he (Gen. H.) and myself have not been on the ground for
some years, your opinion is probably better than ours, or any
we could express to others.
Is General Hazen still sore because he could not have your
fine command, and post, or, being lately moved against his will 
does he take Howard's Wells as a test to hit at both Gen. Sheridan
and you at once, on old scores generally, while saying, as usual
a good word for his backer, General Sherman?
At any rate I hope his letter and its slanders will meet with its
deserts at your hands.
I still take the A&N Journal and so keep more or less trace of your
whereabouts and affairs. Just now I am wondering how 
much of a stay you make at Gibson and why Myrick resigned.
You doubtless know something of the changes in my life, but
may be interested in some explanations.
I think our last correspondence was just after my assignment
to the Ninth Cavalry, "M"Co., which I still believe to be a mistake.
Had I then really expected to serve again with troops I should have
made some effort at a change, altho' advised not to do so, but as it was,
I was allowed to remain at the College at Amherst and I believed

myself safe for two years more there, meanwhile I intended to 
make provision for the then future.
Circumstances prevented however. My position at Amherst
was unchanged, becoming still more pleasant and desirable, up to
the August vacation a year ago. We came down here to
spend that and while here my father suddenly died. I was
left his Executor and Trustee for the family of young children
by the second wife. He had been unfortunate in his
management of affairs here, and I soon found I had upon me 
as an inheritance with this Trust, the tedious arrangement of a
badly complicated estate, the partial support of a family, and
liability for considerable debt. The prospect was anything
but pleasing but it was plain enough that I must give the matter my
undivided attention., I was compelled first to give up my 
place at the College and come here, this I did at first on leave
of absence only, but Secy. Belknap and I did not get on at all well,
he was inclined to grant me no favors, and finally, last December,
I was forced, much against my will, but in obedience to 
my sense of highest personal duty, to resign from the Army.
With nothing else to do, and to simplify the settlement of the 
Estate, I bought everything on the place, rented the Farm for 1872
(of myself as Trustee), and here I am, a Virginia farmer, have been 
such since January.
It is a lovely spot, the one to which I am more attached
than any other on Earth; Martha is at her birthplace and home, 
her parents and my only sister live near by, these things and

the many attractions of the life itself make it most enjoyable
generally. But on the other hand the constantly apparent
fact that I am not a farmer, with the many losses, trials
and disappointments which occur mainly in consequence there
as well as the great labor which falls upon my wife, and 
which tells so sadly upon her, make me feel that my stay
here must be very uncertain.
I hope to close up the settlement of my father's Estate
during the year, but with no Profession to return to, what am 
I to do. -I feel generally that I would rather strave here
than attempt another change or more, but perhaps when the 
hunger began to be felt I should change my mind.
My future is not very clear, but it never has been, yet
has always cleared itself as time passed. So may it yet do!
I have seen Col. W.P. Ross frequently in Washington during
the winter, and some other mutual acquaintances. I am
but 15 miles from the Capital and go to town weekly.
I fear we shall not soon see the beautiful Indian country
again, but won't you be coming East sometime? If 
while I am here, you must let me know, so we can meet.
Mrs. Alvord joins in very sincere regards to Mrs Grierson
and yourself, and the rest of the family, the boys must be
almost men.
Please write when you can,
Ever your friend, most truly
Henry E. Alvord
Lewensville P.O.
Fairfax County, Virginia.
Gen. B.H. Grierson
U.S.A.

Wichita Agency
Sunday, Sept. 8,1872
Dear General,
Have written nothing before because 
I had nothing to write. I must be brief now.
Dr. Parrish was taken sick the day we reached Sill
and has been on his back there ever since.
Last Tuesday I left him, came on with 
Jones and a small escort, and made camp at site
of old Leepor Agency, between here and Cobb.
There we held Council yesterday & day before.
Every tribe and band of these three western agencies
was represented except the Cheyennes. They were
all out so far my message did not reach them in time
but I am to meet them Tuesday at their Agency.
The Kiowas were not well represented, only Son of the
Sun, Fast Bear and Satanta's son, being present, but I
stirred them up and am promised the presence of Lone
Wolf, Kicking Bird and others here next Thursday.
Result of Council - All the promises desired, but 
I took little stock in them. More to the point, I got
every tribe and band to appoint two delegates to accompany
me to Washington.
Of the Comanches you could not name a single chief

or important man, not at the Council, and
altho Padua-comb & Mow-way have not themselves
promised to join our party, they have promised to send
good representative men.
Something may yet occur to break up our plans
so I am not over-confident, but I think
it probable that about the 18th inst, we shall
start from this place with Gov't. transportation
for the R.R. A party of at least forty.
In that case we shall reach the R.R. at Boggy
about the 24th. Just as soon as we get there
I will telegraph you, hoping you can meet us
at Gibson and go up to Sedalia with the party.
We are prepared to recommend in our Report, a conference
at Washington between the Secy Intr, Comr. Indian Affairs
Supt. H. and Gen'l. G. But of that more when
we meet.
Maj. Schofield did very well by me at Sill, but
I saw three things badly needed.
1st. More men - 2nd. More temperance, enforced -
3rd. More respect for the Regtl. Cmdr.
Will write again, when I know more
Yours more truly
Alvord

Witchita Agency
On Washita Rr. In. Ty.
Thursday Sept. 19. 1872
Dear General
Tonight I start East, down 
the Valley, with delegations from every
tribe of the three western Agencies,
except Cheyennes, whom I have not seen.
We expect to reach the R.R. at Atoka
(middle Boggy) on Tuesday or Wednesday
of next week, 24th or 25th, ready to
go North by rail 25th or 26th.
One of the things promised to the Indians
is that they shall see you, on the road.
So I shall telegraph you from Atoka as
soon as I know what train we shall be 
on and depend on you to meet us at Gibson
Sta. and go up part way with us, if not to St. Louis.
Regards to friends, No news at Sill,
Yous most truly
hastily,
Henry E Alvord
Gen'l Grierson
Ft. Gibson

Grand Central Hotel
New York City. October 31st 1872
General,
First of all I must confess to having neglected
you since I came East - yet I have good excuses.
At Washington I found neither Secretary, Asst. Secretary or 
Commissioner and waited impatiently from day to day for the
arrival of some person with whom to do business. Every
day I expected to be able the next to write something definite.
At last Secy. Delano came for a day. I at once entered in
advance of my full report, the recommendation for the trio conference
at Washin. The Secretary then informed me of the fact that Supt. Hoag
on his own application had been ordered to Washington, but could 
not stay long enough to be joined by you, and the Secretary was 
unwilling to decide upon orders for a subsequent meeting until 
he had time to give full attention to the matter. Off he went. 
Com'r. Walker came and Supt. Hoag, the latter returned West and 
we settled down to "straight talk' with the Commissioner. Then
between waiting for the Secretary's return and my crowded hours
and the uncertainty of the time of starting back - my letter to 
you was still further postponed. We finally left W-n
quite suddenly and before again seeing Secy. Delano.
It is certain therefore that no conference will be ordered at present.

Just as we started to the depot to leave Washington_
a week ago tomorrow morning. Mrs. Alvord received Mrs. 
Grierson's letter.  To it I replied that day by telegraph
from Baltimore, that our movements were so uncertain. we did 
not want you to change any of your plans on our account.
I also promised to write you particulars at Jacksonville,
but have found no time until now. Travelling with
such a family involves constant labor and I find it
difficult to command ten minutes alone. Officials,
railroad men, reporters, curiosity seekers and friends crowd
upon me by the dozen.
In the week since we left Washington we have
'done" Balitmore, Philadelphia and New York,
with rides, excursions, interviews, public receptions, &c.
Tomorrow might we start for Chicago where we hope to
arrive on Sunday morning and remain until Tuesday or
Wednesday. Then we go on to Leavenworth and
Lawrence. There the last of next week, the party
divides, the Arrapahoes going to Witchita, the rest via.
New Chicago and Parsons to Atoka.
Mrs. Alvord is with me and will go to the end of
the railroad. If you or Mrs. Grierson are at home we
will arrange to stop at Gibson, otherwise we shall hardly 
leave the train there. We shall be very sorry to

go to the Territory and back without seeing you, but
we know how seldom you and Mrs. Grierson get away
for a trip together, and do not want to interfere in any 
way with your arrangements.
I shall telegraph you from Lawrence to Gibson to find
out where you are, and tell when I pass that point.
We are getting along very well with the Indians and
hope good may result from the visit.
Mrs. Alvord unites with me in kindest
regards to yourself and family.
Yours very truly
Henry E Alvord
B H Grierson
Col. & Bvt. Maj. Gen'l.
U. S. Army

Gardner House,
Chicago, Illinois
November 5, 1872
Dear General,
We reached Chicago Sunday and altho' I intended to stay but one day, we
had such bad weather yesterday that I resolved
to lie over today. This is no better
and we must go forward tomorrow without 
seeing much of Chicago.
The weather and the horse desease have 
prevented my getting about much myself
and I have not yet found Charley and
the Kirks, tho' I mean to today.
I saw Gen. Sheridan and the Forsyths
yesterday. They had just go the detailed 
reports of the McKenzie attack on Mow-way's
camp Sept. 27th. I spent last eve'g
at Genl. Sheridan's house and he told me
among other things that Gen. August was
to reach Fort Gibson from Sill about the
15th, and he (Gen.S.) was to meet him there.

I presume therefore that you will
arrange to be back at Gibson by the
15th and I would like to know whether 
you will be there any earlier.
I expect to reach Lawrence on next
Thursday evening and remain there
until Monday. This will give 
time for a line from Jacksonville to
reach me there, I think.
At any rate when I am ready to
leave Lawrence I shall enquire
whether you are at Gibson, by telegraph
and arrange about Martha's stopping
there accordingly.
At the same time, as I wrote you
from Baltimore, all our movements 
are so very uncertain, that I don't 
want you to make a day's difference
in your plans on our account.
No other news.
Yours very truly
Henry E. Alvord
Gen. Grierson
U.S.A.

Lewensville P.O.
Fairfax County, Virginia
December 22, 1872
Dear General,
It seems to me hardly possible that a 
month has passed since I got home, yet such
is the fact. How the days have flown!
You know something of the cold I had when 
I left Gibson. It developed into a regular siege
of Epizoo' and kept me in the house for a week
after my return. Then, after I had given a couple 
of days to my too long neglected farm, I went 
to town and there staid nearly all the time for
a fortnight. Congress, however, had by this time

General Davidson said, that when the President found out that there were a great many bad Indians among the Comanches, Kiowas and others he determined to separate them, he wanted to bring the good of the tribes to the Agencies and to make war on the bad, on the plains.

    I began last month to separate the good and the bad at Fort Sill and to make an enrollment of them there, giving orders not to let anybody come in, who did not come in and surrender arms and await the action of the Great Father, fixing August 3rd as the last day at which any of these Indians could come in.  Kiowas and Comanches have enrolled time and time again, the conditions under which they could come in, give up their arms &c, have been made known to them, the same kind of a message was sent to Asa-nou-i-ca.
    Last Friday the Captain here [strike] sent me word that the Noconies came in here where they don't belong.  The Wichita agent also sent me word that he did not want them here.  They had no business to come in here

or Fort Sill without complying with instructions to give up arms &c, as required by the Great Father.  As soon as I got this news I got in the saddle and came here to take the Noconies, as prisoners, where they belong.  When I got here I met all the Caddoes, Wichitas and Kiowas as friends, I met them as friends. [underline]   I sent for the Chief of the Noconies and told him what my instructions were, he promised me to go to Sill.  Believing in this fellows word I sent him to his Camp with a guard and as soon as he broke away, my guard fired at him.               So soon as I dismounted my troops to go through the Noconic Camp the cowardly, thieving Kiowas fired into the backs of my soldiers.   I never was so bothered in my life to know what to do, if they had been all hostile men my course was plain, but I did not want to hurt friends.
You know the rest how the Kiowas fired at me from all sides, brunt forage; you know all.  I did not come after Kiowas, I came after Noconies.  The very Kiowas who did this mischief were men with papers in their pockets and were not to leave the Fort Sill reservation.  The Government is going to make this a big war and finial, on all these bad Indians and it wants to gather together all friendly Indians at agencies to keep them out of the trouble. May 15th 1869
Dear General

                          We arrived here yesterday, after a most interesting and successful march of over four hundred and thirty five miles. (435).  Allowing for indirect travel, the distance from Camp Mitchell to Fort Bascom must be at the least over 400 miles.
    We have not a man on the sick list, nor a mule or Wagon injured.
    After we had been four days on our journey, the Kiowas under Lone Wolf and his brother, with about fifty of their warriors and squaws came out to meet us and escorted us a days march, they were drest in their best and showed us no little kindness. Capturing a Bufalo and presenting us with the choicest parts or dinner.  They rode on to our camping ground and Lone Wolf asked for talk,  He said that both he & his tribe were pleased with their reservation and wished to have schools established among them and their children taught to read & write and 'till the soil.  In the Summer he wished to be allowed to hunt the Buffalo, and

and said, if our people were afraid to trust them on the open plains, they might send their agent to accompany them, and watching all their doings report to yourself or General Hazen, returning with them to their Reservation in the Autumn.

       After this we did not meet an Indian on our tramp.  For several days we noticed the footprint of an indian pony as though some messages had preceded us     I was open and frank with Lone Wolf telling him where we were going and the objects of our expedition.  Whether this had anything to do with our being wholly unmolested during the rest of our journey I cannot say but I think it had.
       Corporal Wm Evans Co. C. 6th Infantry being an excellant shot caught us many Bufalo, Turkeys & one Deer so that we had an abundance of game, and I feel under great obligations to him.
       Personally, I feel indebted to every man of the Escort for some act of kindness and I wish here to sincerely thank them.

We were up every morning at dawn and the Sun rose generally with our teams and selves in motion.  We followed Col Howes trail, the first half of the way and then crossed the Canadian and took up with Col Evans line of march.   As we had reckoned on the distance being 350 miles we though we were on top of Fort Bascom some days before we were near it.
       Of course we were vigilant, and yet felt sufficiently secure, to allow our Camp fires to burn late, and when cold sometimes all the night long, for the comfort of the Sentinal on Guard.  We rested all day on Sundays and held Christian worship.  We had enough rain to give us an abundance of fresh water and yet were compelled to lay over but one day on account of storms.

Mills, virtually took command of us, designating our camp, and the routine duties to be performed.   The evening after the day we arrived (on the 6th) Col. Mizner rec'd a telegram from the Indian Agent here informing him that he expected the Kiowas and Comanches to break out and destroy the agency the next day and asking that two companies be sent without delay.  Col. Mizner ordered all our companies and Davis' Co. 4th Cav. (five in all) to start at daylignt (t'was midnight then) and the next morning we started out under Col. Mizner's personal command, Col Mills being left behind presumably in command of the post, but I

learn an Infty Capt (Morgan, 24th) disputed his (Mill's) right to command them, and the matter was finally settled by Gen'l Pope - ordering the 4 Cos. to be taken up for duty as part of the garrison.  Such I learn is the state of affairs there now, the men performing regular post duty.  However, we made a rapid march of 35 miles, and arriving here found everything serene and no signs of disturbance;  the Indians so far from appearing war-like having their families here to draw rations, it being the regular day, and you know, General, from experience, that if they had contemplated a disturbance the first they would do would be to place their families out of danger.  Old Horace Jones, who came with us, laughed at the idea of an out-break even before we left Sill, and everybody must acknowledge he knows something [underline] about these particular Indians. 

   Well, when we got here we found it was a false alarm or a scare on the part of somebody, and Col. Mizner after remaining a day or two to satisfy himself that it was all right, started back for Sill leaving Keyes and I here with our companies and Dr. Smith.  I can't for the life of me tell what they are going to do with us for nobody seems to know.  We are not wanted at Reno, for

the C. O. there (Capt Randall) telegraphed Col Mills that "he had no orders for us, had not applied for us and didn't need us."   So appears as if we were outcasts, nobody wants us.   The other days [strike s]  news reached us that you were on your way to Sill with 4 Cos. & Hd. Qrs., but it appears to have been without foundation, although I was hopeful such might be the case, for I'd be delighted to have you come to Sill to command - that is if I could stay there too with you.   You would be much pleased with Sill, General, for despite the fact that I left it but last year, yet in that short time, Col. Mizner has improved it so that it is by far the prettiest and best post in the west, not even excepting Fort Leavenworth.    This opinion is not only mine but of every officer who see Fort Sill as it stands to-day, and you would laugh to hear the officers of the 10th say "well, the 10th Cav. built it anyhow, therefore, why shouldn't it be a good post"    I was very sorry to learn a few days ago that Mrs Grierson has been quite ill and glad to learn subsequently that she was better.   I trust she has entirely recovered upon the receipt of this.  Whilst I'm thinking of it, General, I desire to thank you most heartily for

Mrs Cooper spoke of it frequently on the journey, and I assure you, General, we both of us appreciated your courtesy on the occasion.  There's no telling how long Keyes & I will be kept here.  As we tell the Indians when they ask us, "maybe so one day may so keep of days", which quotation is, as you will see, from the language of our esteemed brother-officer Richard Henry Pratt - the Christian Soldier.
